It's well written, detailed, and often quite witty — "black holes are not hairy" — but left me unsatisfied and quite confused.A pretty decent overview of the structure and contents can be found at http://www.bookrags.com/studyguide-the-universe-in-a-nutshell/#gsc.tab=0

The first few chapters are easy to understand, but then the content gets exponentially convoluted.So, the 4 stars are for being able to comprehend the first three chapters, the last chapter, and most of the pictures in the rest of the chapters.I may have to read this book again at some point in the future after I re-read Black Holes & Time Warps: Einstein's Outrageous Legacy by Kip S. Thorne!

Evaporating black holes leaking information. Time with a shape. Imaginary time in the form of a sphere. Curled-up dimensions, worm holes and time loops. This is so cool. Stephen Hawking is even cooler, and actually sometimes funny. I really liked this book, but it was not an easy read for me, despite having studied some physics at university. The subject is truely mind-boggling. Lesson learned: Never catch a ride with an alien spaceship from an advanced civilisation, since you can get stuck in an eternal time loop. Provided the aliens have learned how to bend space-time, that is.

I found this much easier to read than "The Brief History of Time" but there were still parts that I had to reread and still didn't get. Stephen Hawking does an excellent job of conveying the overall concepts and the diagrams and illustrations are very helpful. As my post-grad supervisor told me when I was doing my first departmental presentation, if you can get one concept across so that people understand it then you've done a good job, and I think that is the approach that Hawking takes with "The Universe in a Nutshell".

Years ago I tried reading A Brief History of Time and have to admit I didn't make it past the first few chapters. Fast forward and I grabbed this one. It is a lot easier to understand, although there are still parts that make me say 'Huh?' I also caught myself grinning every time I heard the Big Bang Theory as I immediately thought of Sheldon Cooper. Also, I actually learned a few things about string theory and a couple of other terms the guys throw around on the show. Overall, this one is no super overwhelming as I did make it through the entire thing.

If this is a book for the masses. Then I still feel dumb. Hold on tight until the end and all the concepts are put to work to describe what humans are likely experiencing.Favorite concept in the book is that 'intelligence is not really a great survival trait, bacteria will continue to thrive with no intelligence'.Certainly can't fault a person for trying to build their mental model understanding of the universe. I've decided that my passion for "Space" now includes pretty pictures, big rockets and the excitement of exploration. To go boldly where no-one has gone before...

It's an amazing but highly scientific speculative book (At the end) about the modern physics theories that could lead to a theory of everything, a search pursued by physicists since the great unification work of Isaac Newton. The reader will find a nice way to understand the main concepts of physics but some chapters are very hard to understand because the Intuition become insufficient to get the whole idea. Sure you will enjoy the journey that starts when you take the book and swamp into the pictures of an nutshell-like universe

Not as bright as A Brief History Of Time since this book here is supposed to be a sequel.Not to mention of course the repetitive manner of many major headlines that I already read in the Brief History book.But I must say, it's still insightful, especially when it comes to the last part of the book where biology and human fate were discussed.Prof. Hawking added some new thoughts and concepts into this volume that were not mentioned in his earlier editions.3 shiny stars for the last part of the book. the remaining 2 stars were already been given to the Brief History.

Though definitely interesting and important, this book doesn't live up to the legacy of A Brief History of Time. It is quite a bit more complex and, for someone of my level of physics knowledge, quite difficult to understand at certain points. In ABHoT, I never felt this was the case, as even the most unintuitive concepts were explained clearly and made comprehensible. Additionally, the "narrative" of The Universe in a Nutshell is jumpy and non-linear, and I found myself feeling whiplashed between various crazy cosmological theories.

A sequel of A Brief History of Time, with more recent researches and discoveries in theoretical physics field.He discussed the development of unified theory of all fundamental forces of the nature, as well as go deep into explaining some specific topics, such as string theory, M-theory, P-branes,..Just like reading his previous million-copy bestseller, be ready to travel in the surreal journey through eleven dimension world, with amazingly clear language, comprehensible analogies and occasional humor of one of the greatest minds in this century.

I could only read up until chapter 4. Each chapter had become too technical as I progressed. However, these are fell new things that intrigued me:The light emitted by star should have escape velocity more than its gravity otherwise, it becomes a dark star, and probably a black hole! (The first explanation for a blackhole).Light will change its direction by a small angle when it passes near a star because of the curvature of space-time produced by the mass of the starQuasars!

I guess that reading every book that was written by Stephen Hawking can't be a waste of time (especially as he himself works on defining better the definition of time).The book is very short and covers only few topics, relatively fast, but I guess it could be written a bit simpler. Even readers that have some understanding in physics will find themselves lost few times. The famous humor of Hawking dependently makes this book more fun to read.

"One, remember to look up at the stars and not down at your feet. Two, never give up work. Work gives you meaning and purpose and life is empty without it. Three, if you are lucky enough to find love, remember it is there and don’t throw it away."Beautiful images paired with amazing facts and information about our universe. A little harder to understand that Michio Kaku's works, but not quite Master's Degree level writing.

Maybe I'm too dumb or the audiobook wasn't the best way to consume it but this was really hard to follow. I guess I was expecting something more approachable to the every-man. There were a few things that I could follow and it was cool to see just over the horizon of my understanding for a few minutes, but at the end of the day I'm just glad that this book was mercifully short so that I didn't have to abandon reading it. I don't think I'll read any more of his books though.

This is the 5th book on astrophysics that I have read this year and I may be more confused about time, space, m theory, and the origins of the universe than when I started. Still this was delightful little book. It is more technical than an of the previous books that I have read and Hawking does attempt to simplify some of the ideas but they are still difficult to comprehend. The line 'intelligence may not be nesaccarv for survival, in fact it may get in the way' came from this book.

If you're into cosmology and theoretical physics then this book is for you. After I finished "Brief Answers to the Big Questions", I was so impressed and wowed by Stephen Hawking's thinking comprehension and vision so I started this book. In my opinion, "Brief Answers to the Big Questions" has everything this book can offer and even in a more simplified delivery for someone with very basic understanding of cosmology and theoretical physics but still curious about the universe.

Like others, I opted for the popular audiobook. It's a predictably heavy topic and i'm sure more went over my head than went in but the parts I could grasp I found incredibly fascinating; particularly wormholes and time travel in chapter five, and genetic modification in chapter six. What is also a pleasant surprise is how funny Hawkins can be and how he sprinkles popular cultural references throughout to help the reader relate to his theories.

Mr. Hawking has a great sense of humor that comes through in his writings. Much of this book was more than my P-brain could comprehend, but I appreciate his trying to simplify it for non-scientific readers. He and Carl Sagan were amazing in how they stimulate interest in science among young people. I particularly enjoyed his discussion of what the future of human DNA and AI may be as we incorporate computers within our bodies.

I wasn't quite as mind-blown by this one as by A Brief History of Time. I found many of the graphics distracting rather than clarifying. A lot of the same ground was covered in this as in the previous book, which many theories taken a little further, and a few extra ideas thrown in. Overall, I quite enjoyed it, just not quite as much as A Brief History of Time; definitely read that one first.

Not as easy to understand as his earlier works, but still, informative and insightful information from perhaps the sharpest mind on the planet. I would love to have an evolution discussion with Dr. Hawking, as a more biologically trained science teacher...his perspective from the physics side fascinates me!Thank you Dr. Hawking for all you do.

Cool concepts, but it glosses over a lot of details. I guess it's meant to convey big-picture information to Plebs like me without getting bogged down in proofs that I wouldn't understand anyway; I enjoyed it, so I guess it worked. This book is pretty old, though, so I can't help wondering if a lot of the science is more well understood and fleshed out today.

Considering how crazy high level these concepts are, I felt like I understood more than I expected to. I feel like I probably should have read this one in print because I would have comprehended more.....but I don't care enough to actually do so. Also, Stephen Hawking is kind of an ass, which sandwiched in science concepts and this very proper british voice is pretty funny.

I mean... I could follow some ideas?!? This isn't a reflection on Hawking however, I like his writing style but I chose to 'read' this book to challenge myself and read outside my comfort zone so mission accomplished? I dunno, maybe next time I want to revisit will buy a physical copy and have a bunch of index cards and highlighters at my disposal.
hawking really breaks it down for you. but, wow... seriously, how smart is that guy?
Even with my strong scientific background, this book sometimes made my brain hurt.
I kind of understood it. Yay for me!
i re-read this, over ten years later, and sadly, nope, still can't process everything hawking says......but i gave it a good (second) try lol
I got bored so quickly :/I'm not in the mood, sorry Stephen!
"O brane new world.That has such creatures in't." Wow. Just wow.
the book is fantastic and emotionally
i love this book
The most interesting science book you could read!
I think I need to listen to this audio book again!!!

Stephen Hawking, who died in 2018, was a preeminent physicist, and this is one of several books that he wrote describing physics for a non-mathematical audience. In it he discusses such things as whether time had a beginning, the nature of black holes, and progress toward a complete unified theory to explain the universe. I found the book fascinating, primarily for the science but also for incidental remarks about the scientists.To my surprise, it was a fairly quick read, the prose free of abtruse contortions, and the text interspersed with diagrams and illustrations. That said, there were times when I was deeply perplexed. I read chapter two twice to understand it better, and there were five places in the subsequent chapters where I wrote question marks to indicate my confusion. Chapter six, where Hawking turns from physics to biology and computers, appealed to me less than the rest of the book. (I found myself questioning his assertions there in a way that I didn't in the physics sections.)I mentioned that I found this a quicker read than I'd expected. The downside to that is that I'd have appreciated more detail, but that may be hard to achieve without getting into nitty-gritty mathematics. Overall, this strikes me as a very good introduction to the areas of theoretical physics that Hawking studied. Interested readers, myself included, can then scurry away to find further books on the subject. Highly recommended.About my book reviews: I try to review every book I read, including those that I don't end up enjoying. The reviews are not scholarly, but just indicate my reaction as a reader, reading being my addiction. I am miserly with 5-star reviews; 4 stars means I liked a book very much; 3 stars means I liked it; 2 stars means I didn't like it (though often the 2-star books are very popular with other readers and/or are by authors whose other work I've loved).

Stephen Hawking, A great theoretical physicist, cosmologist whose previous book "A Brief History of Time" was a phenomenal success. Since its first publication, there have been numerous scientific developments and technological advancements which has led us to observe micro and macro cosmic world in much more detail than ever. "The Universe in a Nutshell" delivers a full understanding of universe ranging from quantum mechanics to time travel to black holes. More than just information, this book compels the reader to think. For example (the best part I liked, because Aliens): Stephen asks how does one account for our lack of extraterrestrial visitors? He reasons, It could be that there is an advanced race out there which is aware of our existence but is leaving us to stew in our own primitive juices. However, it is doubtful it would be so considerate to a lower life-form: do most of us worry how many insects and earthworms we squash underfoot? A more reasonable explanation is that there is a very low probability either of life developing on other planets or of that life developing intelligence. Because we claim to be intelligent, though perhaps without much ground, we tend to see intelligence as an inevitable consequence of evolution. However, one can question that. It is not clear that intelligence has much survival value. Bacteria do very well without intelligence and will survive us if our so-called intelligence causes us to wipe ourselves out in a nuclear war (which doesn't seem so far fetched right now, given global tensions). So he says, as we explore the galaxy we may find primitive life, but we are not likely to find beings like us.

This book can be summed up in three words - My brain hurts.The beginning of this book feels very similar to A Brief History of Time (as a sort of primer for what is to come), but goes into even more detail and covers a number of new topics that the first book either didn't address or hadn't been theorized at the time.It is also much more difficult to wrap your head around. Not really to a scientific or mathematical degree (no need to have a PhD to understand most concepts in the book!), Hawking does a great job putting things in perspective for the layman, but the theories involved are just brain-warpingly difficult to truly grasp. I'm gonna be honest, I only really understood the first half. I was more or less completely lost by the second half (namely cosmic strings, p-branes, the Chronology Protection Conjecture, and the mathematical model of explaining our universe using multi-dimensional branes). It gets intense and likely requires multiple readings to understand properly.Anyway, for crazy nerds like me, I think this book is amazing. It is the best book (including A Brief History of Time) that I've ever read that puts the current (using it lightly, as it is 17 years "outdated" for lack of a better word) understanding of our universe and the fundamental laws that govern it in perspective for a regular, although enthusiastic, individual. Hawking does a brilliant job explaining high-level concepts and tries his best to remain unbiased as he understands there is no way we can TRULY know something for a fact, but we can have thorough confidence for/against it.Anyway, great book. I highly recommend it if you're a science/space/physics nerd like me.

SummaryHawking works to present fundamental theories of the universe in a way that's digestible to the layman. Pros:- I think Hawking more-or-less succeeded in his efforts to demystify "life, the universe, and everything," as currently understood by our modern scientific models. - I enjoyed Hawking's wry humor; if I recall correctly, he throws in more jokes than The Grand Design.- The reader's performance (and his accent) matched well with the material presented.Cons:- Audiobook format means that figures are lost (though they are only explicitly referenced a few times). - Despite Hawking's best efforts, the material is still incredibly dense. Beyond that, science simply doesn't have all the answers. This second point isn't a con, of course, but worth noting.- I sometimes found myself drifting to sleep while listening to this audiobook. I don't think it was the material present (because I found it interesting), or the presenter's voice (which is appropriately British and spirited), however.ConclusionI enjoyed the work. Also, given that it was published almost two decades ago, I'm curious to know how science has advanced, and how Hawking's thinking has changed over time. I'll have to seek out Brief Answers to the Big Questions, I suppose.

This is a shorter version of A Brief History of Time by Stephen Hawing. It is shorter because the author felt that his earlier work contained too much preliminary material so that many readers did not get to the main topics later in the book. This current book was meant to sidestep that matter and in doing so he lost a star with me.If you are not familiar with the material already, the book is going to seem like it is moving too quickly. You are taking for granted that the author is correct, or at least giving a balanced view of the subject. This is what I normally call a "little old lady" book. A little old lady wants to cross the street, so the author kindly takes her hand and leads her across. He is not trying to teach her how to cross the street on her own. He doesn't explain the red and green lights, pushing the pedestrian cross button, so that next time she could cross by herself. He just leads her across. That is both good and bad. Your mileage may vary.Personally I think folks should read A Brief History of Time. It contains most of the same material, better explained.I will probably read this book again to review the knowledge I already have, but not to gain further knowledge.

In this book, Stephen proposes more independent chapters compared to "A Brief Story of Time", claiming that it wouldn't be necessary to depend on a continuous sequence of concepts. However, I missed a lot of the previous storytelling and at some points I felt like reading a heavy academic book. The idea of indexing images to help explain some main concepts is pleasant to me, but some of them are just graphically hard to admire, to be honest. Talking about the bright side, Stephen is a great writer and always makes me wonder about how small our existence in this world is compared to the beginning of the universe and how everything is so fragile and ephemeral. The parts where he explains the expansion of the universe, the possibility of time travel through wormholes, and when he describes some provoking points about the future of human race were the highlights of this book. The reason I gave it 3 stars is not because it presents complex theories that are much harder to keep up than the previous book, but due to using repetition hoping it would help us understand some concepts that are misplaced, telling 1000 things almost grasping for air. The book felt like it had much more than just one author, maybe because they were looking for another bestseller, losing its previous storytelling and with a very weird closure. Still, I look forward to writing a better review on "Brief Answers to Big Questions" soon.

I read A Brief History of Time prior to reading this book, and there is a lot of overlap, hence the slightly lower rating. This book feels like a more summarized version of the concepts discussed in Brief History, plus 30% new content. The new content, such as strings and branes, feels less “science-heavy”, which is probably because these are brand new topics that physicists are still exploring. They are very exciting to read about and has a fiction-like quality. In general, the language and writing style in this book feels much more toned down. The captions and extra info in sidebars are helpful, but not required for understanding the main content.If you want more in-depth and comprehensive discussion of concepts, I recommend A Brief History of Time. It includes many introductory physics concepts and their development over time. However, it is a heavier read and written in a linear fashion. If one got stuck at an earlier chapter, it is harder to progress.If you want a more summarized version of concepts, and a brief introduction to the new theories being researched, The Universe in a Nutshell might be a better choice. This book is not written in a linear fashion, so even if one got super confused by one chapter, it won’t affect understanding of the subsequent chapters. I was personally really confused by chapter five and I am not sure what the entire chapter described, but I was able to understand the following chapters well.

Most of the things I knew about astrophysics were from SF books and shows which, while some are well documented and some even written by professionals in the field (I’m looking at you, Alastair Reynolds), they’re still speculative in nature and it’s hard to judge where real physics ends and fantasy begins with them. I therefore found Stephen Hawking’s The Universe in a Nutshell very illuminating, clearly defining some of the concepts I had come across in SF books (singularities, black holes, dark matter), but also introducing me to many I had only heard about in passing (superstring theory, P-branes).I would have liked to read an updated, more recent version of it, as some of the chapters left me wondering what progress has been made in the field in the last nearly twenty years since the book came out. I also felt that at times Stephen Hawking, as a supporter of certain theories, failed to give a complete view of a subject, presenting instead the theories he thought valid. That’s to be expected since he was a practicing physicist I suppose, but it did make me curious about what other theories might be out there. Although a few concepts flew over my head, I did find most of the book to be accessible and the explanations easy to follow. It’s definitely a good place to start diving into the subject!

This was probably the heaviest book I’ve ever read. It covered everything from how Einstein’s theory of relativity served as the building block for basically everything we know about the universe, the plausibility of more fantastic topics such as time travel and being able to tell the future, how it was discovered that there is, in fact, a finite beginning to existence, and the exploration of black holes and wormholes.There was so much information and so many new concepts in this book that I could probably re-read it at least ten more times and glean about as much new information as I did this time around with each read-through.Einstein is blamed for creating nuclear weapons. It's pointed out in this book that he had just stumbled upon some natural laws and that he should not be solely blamed for the existence of nuclear weapons. Also, this book illustrates a plain example of how ignorance can put a halt to science. Einstein left Germany just before the Nazi hunt for Jewish scientists began. If there had been no hateful Nazi party, more progress might have been made and a European atomic bomb may have been created earlier on. Progress was lost as a direct consequence of ignorance and unfounded hatred.

200 pages is not counted as a thick book but it’s still quite a challenge to me. Most of reason is my lacking knowledge in physics then most of time i read this book i moved between Partially understand to Totally not understand.I tried to understand this book in most common and reasonable way that I can.Funny is even though it’s hard to read and even in Vietnamese I still dont understand what I am reading I still read and enjoy it. It raise me more interest in time, universe even more, this book also help me to enlarge my knowledge, theory of everything, how universe run and universe structures which lead to theory that the space- time we are living is just 3 dimension space but it can be up to 10 dimensions, just like layers after layers but maybe layer is too small to see or feel it. There are so may theories about universe, black hole or time-space which makes me feel overwhelmed and excited at the same time. This book is short, that’s kind of textbook which contains a vast of knowledge about universe and space and time which illustrate universe with images and theories attached.I suddenly want to tell my old friend that I read this book and intend to move to Elon Musk book which is 2 or 3 years ago i would never think I would read that kind of book in the future. Somehow right now i enjoy reading that kind of book.

In commemoration of the passing of one of the best minds of our century, Stephen Hawking, I decided that I would read some of his work. I can tell you that he is indeed one of the best minds and that this book is really good. I rated the book 5 stars because it was one of the most interesting and mind bending books I have read in a while. This book, The Universe in a Nutshell, was written by Stephen Hawking for the intent of explaining the universe on much simpler terms. He does an excellent job at explaining almost impossible concepts to grasp like the theory of relativity and quantum mechanics. He does it in a way that allows the average person to have a brief understanding and knowledge on the subjects. There is a reason why it is a New York Times Bestseller and I would strongly recommend this book for anyone who is even a little interested in science or people who just want a difficult yet interesting read. It will help you gain a better understanding of the universe we live in and make you all the better for it.

First off, I loved how the book was concepted to look like an ecyclopedia, with less text and many picturesque details. I wish I was more educated on these things to understand the author better though, but that's my fault. Mr Hawking did a spledid job simplifying some pretty complex things and presenting them in a way that almost anyone can understand. And all that, followed by his witty humor and jokes, made this book an amazing reading experience. I will be returning to my notes to remind myself of the things I'd like to remember- these things that actually make the science of our existence, ours and everything else's, yet we peacefully swim through our everyday lives completely ignorant and uninterested in something that should concern all of us. I wonder where we'd all be if it wasn't for people who dared to wonder and think further than known and look beyond mundane triviality. Our planet lacks optimistic minds, who still perfectly understand what pain and loss is, like this great person did.

Loved it.But it also shows why deep physics and astronomy nowadays cannot be fully understood without the mathematical knowledge.Some passages try to explain recent discoveries in the fields of quantum physics and string theory in a basic language and they simply make no sense at all (well, at least to me).I am pretty sure I understood a lot of the book's concepts in terms of what they mean in the human current comprehension of the universe, but some of the other bits (such as a particle spinning 360º and NOT ending up in the starting position) make no sense to me at all, proving that they might only work properly in the mathematical demonstrations.I hope to make some more advanced reading in the mathematics and basic physics to further my astrophysics knowledges in the future. The book is a very pleasant starting point, but no one should stop there. The same is valid for it's "prequel", Hawking's "A brief history of time".

Rating 3.75. In this book Stephen Hawking gives a non-technical overview of the theor(ies) of relativity, quantum mechanics, the nature of space-time, parallel universes, the potential for time travel, and the likelihood of encountering intelligent life in the universe. I listened to this book twice in audio format - the first time to grasp the terminology at a high level and the second to actually think through the concepts. While Hawking states that the book was written for those without a background in physics some of the concepts were tricky to understand the first time through. Hawking also has a frustrating habit of back-referencing to concepts introduced briefly in previous chapters without ever providing a sufficiently in depth explanation of the concept. I would recommend the text form of the book instead of the audio format since the text contains figures and graphs which aren't described in the audio format.

We are in 2001, inspired by Hamlet, Hawking is compiling what we know about the universe's shape, its properties (beginning, age, mass, expansion and so on) and its singularities (black holes). The text and figures are palatable to any curious person and his arguments are supported by relativity, quantum mechanics and his own theories on black holes. The whole thing is beautifully illustrated. The stunning illustrations complement the text in a fine tuned symbiosis almost like atoms holding each other in an interesting molecule. As a result, this book plays with your perception of time flow while reading it. When your stamina is running low (say you are about to run for coffee) here comes another illustration to keep you awake. And then you get back to digesting the text. But suddenly Hawking throws a joke, bet with his friend or honest assessment on humans (e.g. "Humans don't have a very good record of intelligent behavior"). This is very entertaining and informative.

This book I listened to as an audiobook after I became interested in the scientific view point, one which I have not had much exposure to, seeing as I was raised in a religious family. I loved it. It introduced a whole new world to me, with so many mysterious forces that has left humans scrambling to explain. It was well explained and organized. It didn't jump all over the place and should have been easy to understand. But I didn't understand half of what was in there, I was pretty much lost the whole time. But, I hope to understand some day, and that's really all anyone can do. I will give this 4 stars but more for a personal reason, this book has captured my interest and I now have a whole new genre of books to explore. It isn't very long but does take a while (or forever) to fully understand pretty much the whole timeline of scientific discoveries known to us. However, it's worth it and I have enjoyed this immensely.

Not sure where I stand on this book, just that it was interesting to see what Hawking's beliefs were. I never really knew he was so opposed to Einstein's theories, nor did I know that he believed some of the things that would be classified as sci-fi. For what it sought to accomplish, I guess I could say it was a good book. However, I am more inclined to not accept some of the things he has stated after reading this book. He paints a very strange picture of the world we live in, and although a lot of the stuff cannot be proven, I find it very interesting. Things like time travel and aliens, and even parallel universes. To say I agree with his work would be a lie, but to say it is not interesting is also a lie. So I am forced to look at it as just one man's very strange opinion of the world we live in, and cannot really say I agree with most of it, and for that, I have to give this book 2 stars.

His crash course on space. Reads like a textbook on theoretical physics and cosmology, but with some personality and humor. There’s illustrations or pictures on almost every page, which was much needed and appreciated to visualize whatever is being explained. The only drawback is the lack of accessibility to anyone outside of a math/science background. Constants, integers, and pulsars are referenced casually. A violin is used to explain string theory in three paragraphs. There’s still plenty to gain from a general understanding of what’s being discussed. Hawking’s humor comes unexpectedly, like making a wheelchair joke while explaining quantum theory. His chapter on the future of humanity was great and discussed our exponential growth problem, modifying DNA, and the electric and chemical limitations of both our brains and computers. Then he sends the reader on a real trip in the last chapter with M-theory and branes.

I found this more accessible than A Briefer History of Time, however, it is starting to feel a bit dated in some of the lingo and speculation of the future. I would call it a good starting text on understanding astrophysics. Some technical jargon, some silliness, but great general information delivered in a way that most people could at least grasp. I know I started to get lost in some of the details in the end chapters but it still maintained my interest.The most positive aspect is the lack of the author's preferences in the book. It is presented as fact with the science backing it explained as plainly as possible. I contrast it to some of the Neil deGrasse Tyson I have read where you can feel the superiority complex oozing through the text.Dated but still a nice read since most of the principles have not changed.

I read this as part of the combined Illustrated Brief History/Universe in a Nutshell. For the first volume, I thought that Hawking strikes a good balance between superficiality and complexity. He manages to cover topics as advanced as black hole radiation, naked singularities, imaginary time, CPT symmetry, etc., without intimidating the reader too much. This time, however, Hawking outdid himself. His discussions about cosmic strings and shadow branes are so glib and shallow, that they seemed almost silly - like they were intended more to blow the reader's mind than to leave him with any meaningful understanding. It was a short and fun read, so it didn't bother me that much, and it did leave me with the desire to read about these topics from an author who's not afraid to challenge his reader somewhat with the actual mathematics.

Amazing book. I consider myself an absolute zero when it comes to the subjects of quantum physics, string theory etc. But I was actually able to grasp some of the concepts explained in this book. Stephen Hawking is one of the greatest minds of this planet and having a book explaining some of the most complex mathematical challenges that he worked on is amazing. Specially when it is so easy to follow and being able to roughly understand a lot of the concepts explained here.Of course I will need to read the book a few more times to try to make sense of some areas that are a bit harder to understand, but overall I recommend this book to anyone that is curious about how the universe works, including quantum mechanics, M theory and even time tavel. Probably not great if you are already knowledgeable about these, but I would still give it a go.5 stars from me for sure.

This was a super interesting, quite quick listen. I think based on knowing there are pictures that I would have gotten more from the book from reading a physical copy. I was doing so well following the book until he started talking about cosmic strings and them being in conical shapes, that got me pretty lost. So time travel is a bit beyond my comprehension I guess. I was understanding relativity a bit better than high school. But yeah overall this was just an informative book. Made me think about how future generations are going to be screwed for real estate space if we don't get some type of space travel going. How fun.Overall would recommend as a once off read. Would recommend the actual book over the audio book. Also would recommend if you like hearing a physicist be sassy... I love that about Stephen Hawking. He was smart and sassy. Rating is 3.5/5 stars.

"Shine bright like a diamond! "- Rihanna said about love, and I want to use it to describe about this book. It is easy for people like me - who never pay too much attention about physics, chemistry,.. or any kind of science - to understand, every words seemed quite academic now just come right to my brain, every theorem used to be so strange to me, now I grasp it. Reading this book, I can feel Stephen Hawking's passion in each sentences. By some ways, he passes me his flame passion. Now I am more curious about the world we are living, how it work, anh what it used to be. I just want to send him my love and my respect, I will support you every seconds. And I hope all of you will have excellent experience like me. Thanks!

Having read A brief history of time in French when it came out all those years ago I thought I would treat myself to this more luxurious edition of its sequel.The effect of this book on my mind was not as strong as I had hoped. Perhaps this is because I have read many other popular science books since then and indeed also studied physics; I am now much more familiar with notions such as space-time, quantum physics. and glowing black holes.Stephen Hawking did a tremendous job with his original book, it truly revolutionised the popular science genre, but perhaps due to its over focus on black holes to the detriment of other topics, this particular title is not a book that would be recommended to first readers of the genre.Perhaps stick to the original.

Outstanding!Hawking has the gift of explaining things of extreme complexity in a very simple way. The book is a pleasant intelectual trip into the laws of universe. For me as humanist, the book was eye-opening and, sometimes, mind-blowing experience. I finally managed to get some understanding of black holes, theory of relativity, m-theory, string theory, and few other things about physics and the universe.Besides having fun I learned answers to few important questions:- is it possible to time travel?- how long does it take until the universe will collapse?- how long time do human beings have until the Earth is not enough?PS Everything is random.Highly recommended.

Listened to the audiobook. The subject is very interesting and there is a gentle sense of humor. Still, some parts were hard to follow (even though I did two years toward a physics degree), maybe due to missing the illustrations or maybe just the depth/unfamiliarity of the subject matter. I think sometimes a handwaving explanation is more confusing than a detailed one, so even though I understand why the author wouldn't assume the reader understands calculus, etc., I don't know if glossing over such difficult/outlandish material really makes it any easier to grasp. I'll probably listen to this again sometime, or better yet, read the book.

Probably 3.5. Was really interesting stuff but I feel as though audiobook is not the best way to absorb the content if you don't already have extensive knowledge of physics. It's a lot to wrap your head around and fully take in, something I feel I would've been able to do much better it I'd read it at my own pace, and looked things up as I was reading, rather than the narrator's pace. There was also a lot of repetition, which I didn't mind too much, but I imagine that if I were a physicist I'd be a bit annoyed. So I feel it would've been better if it was either written for experts or dumbed down a lot more for novices, rather than trying to please both.

It's very possible that some of this went over my head. It's also very possible that this book is not well suited to audio format. Regardless, I found this a little disappointing. I'm a fan of both Hawking's work and the man himself, but I found this book didn't captivate me or make a significant change to my model of reality. It's well written, detailed, and often quite witty — "black holes are not hairy" — but left me unsatisfied and quite confused.A pretty decent overview of the structure and contents can be found at http://www.bookrags.com/studyguide-the-universe-in-a-nutshell/#gsc.tab=0

The first few chapters are easy to understand, but then the content gets exponentially convoluted.So, the 4 stars are for being able to comprehend the first three chapters, the last chapter, and most of the pictures in the rest of the chapters.I may have to read this book again at some point in the future after I re-read Black Holes & Time Warps: Einstein's Outrageous Legacy by Kip S. Thorne!

Evaporating black holes leaking information. Time with a shape. Imaginary time in the form of a sphere. Curled-up dimensions, worm holes and time loops. This is so cool. Stephen Hawking is even cooler, and actually sometimes funny. I really liked this book, but it was not an easy read for me, despite having studied some physics at university. The subject is truely mind-boggling. Lesson learned: Never catch a ride with an alien spaceship from an advanced civilisation, since you can get stuck in an eternal time loop. Provided the aliens have learned how to bend space-time, that is.

I found this much easier to read than "The Brief History of Time" but there were still parts that I had to reread and still didn't get. Stephen Hawking does an excellent job of conveying the overall concepts and the diagrams and illustrations are very helpful. As my post-grad supervisor told me when I was doing my first departmental presentation, if you can get one concept across so that people understand it then you've done a good job, and I think that is the approach that Hawking takes with "The Universe in a Nutshell".

Years ago I tried reading A Brief History of Time and have to admit I didn't make it past the first few chapters. Fast forward and I grabbed this one. It is a lot easier to understand, although there are still parts that make me say 'Huh?' I also caught myself grinning every time I heard the Big Bang Theory as I immediately thought of Sheldon Cooper. Also, I actually learned a few things about string theory and a couple of other terms the guys throw around on the show. Overall, this one is no super overwhelming as I did make it through the entire thing.

If this is a book for the masses. Then I still feel dumb. Hold on tight until the end and all the concepts are put to work to describe what humans are likely experiencing.Favorite concept in the book is that 'intelligence is not really a great survival trait, bacteria will continue to thrive with no intelligence'.Certainly can't fault a person for trying to build their mental model understanding of the universe. I've decided that my passion for "Space" now includes pretty pictures, big rockets and the excitement of exploration. To go boldly where no-one has gone before...

It's an amazing but highly scientific speculative book (At the end) about the modern physics theories that could lead to a theory of everything, a search pursued by physicists since the great unification work of Isaac Newton. The reader will find a nice way to understand the main concepts of physics but some chapters are very hard to understand because the Intuition become insufficient to get the whole idea. Sure you will enjoy the journey that starts when you take the book and swamp into the pictures of an nutshell-like universe

Not as bright as A Brief History Of Time since this book here is supposed to be a sequel.Not to mention of course the repetitive manner of many major headlines that I already read in the Brief History book.But I must say, it's still insightful, especially when it comes to the last part of the book where biology and human fate were discussed.Prof. Hawking added some new thoughts and concepts into this volume that were not mentioned in his earlier editions.3 shiny stars for the last part of the book. the remaining 2 stars were already been given to the Brief History.

Though definitely interesting and important, this book doesn't live up to the legacy of A Brief History of Time. It is quite a bit more complex and, for someone of my level of physics knowledge, quite difficult to understand at certain points. In ABHoT, I never felt this was the case, as even the most unintuitive concepts were explained clearly and made comprehensible. Additionally, the "narrative" of The Universe in a Nutshell is jumpy and non-linear, and I found myself feeling whiplashed between various crazy cosmological theories.

A sequel of A Brief History of Time, with more recent researches and discoveries in theoretical physics field.He discussed the development of unified theory of all fundamental forces of the nature, as well as go deep into explaining some specific topics, such as string theory, M-theory, P-branes,..Just like reading his previous million-copy bestseller, be ready to travel in the surreal journey through eleven dimension world, with amazingly clear language, comprehensible analogies and occasional humor of one of the greatest minds in this century.

I could only read up until chapter 4. Each chapter had become too technical as I progressed. However, these are fell new things that intrigued me:The light emitted by star should have escape velocity more than its gravity otherwise, it becomes a dark star, and probably a black hole! (The first explanation for a blackhole).Light will change its direction by a small angle when it passes near a star because of the curvature of space-time produced by the mass of the starQuasars!

I guess that reading every book that was written by Stephen Hawking can't be a waste of time (especially as he himself works on defining better the definition of time).The book is very short and covers only few topics, relatively fast, but I guess it could be written a bit simpler. Even readers that have some understanding in physics will find themselves lost few times. The famous humor of Hawking dependently makes this book more fun to read.

"One, remember to look up at the stars and not down at your feet. Two, never give up work. Work gives you meaning and purpose and life is empty without it. Three, if you are lucky enough to find love, remember it is there and don’t throw it away."Beautiful images paired with amazing facts and information about our universe. A little harder to understand that Michio Kaku's works, but not quite Master's Degree level writing.

Maybe I'm too dumb or the audiobook wasn't the best way to consume it but this was really hard to follow. I guess I was expecting something more approachable to the every-man. There were a few things that I could follow and it was cool to see just over the horizon of my understanding for a few minutes, but at the end of the day I'm just glad that this book was mercifully short so that I didn't have to abandon reading it. I don't think I'll read any more of his books though.

This is the 5th book on astrophysics that I have read this year and I may be more confused about time, space, m theory, and the origins of the universe than when I started. Still this was delightful little book. It is more technical than an of the previous books that I have read and Hawking does attempt to simplify some of the ideas but they are still difficult to comprehend. The line 'intelligence may not be nesaccarv for survival, in fact it may get in the way' came from this book.

If you're into cosmology and theoretical physics then this book is for you. After I finished "Brief Answers to the Big Questions", I was so impressed and wowed by Stephen Hawking's thinking comprehension and vision so I started this book. In my opinion, "Brief Answers to the Big Questions" has everything this book can offer and even in a more simplified delivery for someone with very basic understanding of cosmology and theoretical physics but still curious about the universe.

Like others, I opted for the popular audiobook. It's a predictably heavy topic and i'm sure more went over my head than went in but the parts I could grasp I found incredibly fascinating; particularly wormholes and time travel in chapter five, and genetic modification in chapter six. What is also a pleasant surprise is how funny Hawkins can be and how he sprinkles popular cultural references throughout to help the reader relate to his theories.

Mr. Hawking has a great sense of humor that comes through in his writings. Much of this book was more than my P-brain could comprehend, but I appreciate his trying to simplify it for non-scientific readers. He and Carl Sagan were amazing in how they stimulate interest in science among young people. I particularly enjoyed his discussion of what the future of human DNA and AI may be as we incorporate computers within our bodies.

I wasn't quite as mind-blown by this one as by A Brief History of Time. I found many of the graphics distracting rather than clarifying. A lot of the same ground was covered in this as in the previous book, which many theories taken a little further, and a few extra ideas thrown in. Overall, I quite enjoyed it, just not quite as much as A Brief History of Time; definitely read that one first.

Not as easy to understand as his earlier works, but still, informative and insightful information from perhaps the sharpest mind on the planet. I would love to have an evolution discussion with Dr. Hawking, as a more biologically trained science teacher...his perspective from the physics side fascinates me!Thank you Dr. Hawking for all you do.

Cool concepts, but it glosses over a lot of details. I guess it's meant to convey big-picture information to Plebs like me without getting bogged down in proofs that I wouldn't understand anyway; I enjoyed it, so I guess it worked. This book is pretty old, though, so I can't help wondering if a lot of the science is more well understood and fleshed out today.

Considering how crazy high level these concepts are, I felt like I understood more than I expected to. I feel like I probably should have read this one in print because I would have comprehended more.....but I don't care enough to actually do so. Also, Stephen Hawking is kind of an ass, which sandwiched in science concepts and this very proper british voice is pretty funny.

I mean... I could follow some ideas?!? This isn't a reflection on Hawking however, I like his writing style but I chose to 'read' this book to challenge myself and read outside my comfort zone so mission accomplished? I dunno, maybe next time I want to revisit will buy a physical copy and have a bunch of index cards and highlighters at my disposal.

Amazing book. I consider myself an absolute zero when it comes to the subjects of quantum physics, string theory etc. But I was actually able to grasp some of the concepts explained in this book. Stephen Hawking is one of the greatest minds of this planet and having a book explaining some of the most complex mathematical challenges that he worked on is amazing. Specially when it is so easy to follow and being able to roughly understand a lot of the concepts explained here.Of course I will need to read the book a few more times to try to make sense of some areas that are a bit harder to understand, but overall I recommend this book to anyone that is curious about how the universe works, including quantum mechanics, M theory and even time tavel. Probably not great if you are already knowledgeable about these, but I would still give it a go.5 stars from me for sure.

This was a super interesting, quite quick listen. I think based on knowing there are pictures that I would have gotten more from the book from reading a physical copy. I was doing so well following the book until he started talking about cosmic strings and them being in conical shapes, that got me pretty lost. So time travel is a bit beyond my comprehension I guess. I was understanding relativity a bit better than high school. But yeah overall this was just an informative book. Made me think about how future generations are going to be screwed for real estate space if we don't get some type of space travel going. How fun.Overall would recommend as a once off read. Would recommend the actual book over the audio book. Also would recommend if you like hearing a physicist be sassy... I love that about Stephen Hawking. He was smart and sassy. Rating is 3.5/5 stars.

"Shine bright like a diamond! "- Rihanna said about love, and I want to use it to describe about this book. It is easy for people like me - who never pay too much attention about physics, chemistry,.. or any kind of science - to understand, every words seemed quite academic now just come right to my brain, every theorem used to be so strange to me, now I grasp it. Reading this book, I can feel Stephen Hawking's passion in each sentences. By some ways, he passes me his flame passion. Now I am more curious about the world we are living, how it work, anh what it used to be. I just want to send him my love and my respect, I will support you every seconds. And I hope all of you will have excellent experience like me. Thanks!

It's very possible that some of this went over my head. It's also very possible that this book is not well suited to audio format. Regardless, I found this a little disappointing. I'm a fan of both Hawking's work and the man himself, but I found this book didn't captivate me or make a significant change to my model of reality. It's well written, detailed, and often quite witty — "black holes are not hairy" — but left me unsatisfied and quite confused.A pretty decent overview of the structure and contents can be found at http://www.bookrags.com/studyguide-the-universe-in-a-nutshell/#gsc.tab=0

The first few chapters are easy to understand, but then the content gets exponentially convoluted.So, the 4 stars are for being able to comprehend the first three chapters, the last chapter, and most of the pictures in the rest of the chapters.I may have to read this book again at some point in the future after I re-read Black Holes & Time Warps: Einstein's Outrageous Legacy by Kip S. Thorne!

Evaporating black holes leaking information. Time with a shape. Imaginary time in the form of a sphere. Curled-up dimensions, worm holes and time loops. This is so cool. Stephen Hawking is even cooler, and actually sometimes funny. I really liked this book, but it was not an easy read for me, despite having studied some physics at university. The subject is truely mind-boggling. Lesson learned: Never catch a ride with an alien spaceship from an advanced civilisation, since you can get stuck in an eternal time loop. Provided the aliens have learned how to bend space-time, that is.

I found this much easier to read than "The Brief History of Time" but there were still parts that I had to reread and still didn't get. Stephen Hawking does an excellent job of conveying the overall concepts and the diagrams and illustrations are very helpful. As my post-grad supervisor told me when I was doing my first departmental presentation, if you can get one concept across so that people understand it then you've done a good job, and I think that is the approach that Hawking takes with "The Universe in a Nutshell".

Years ago I tried reading A Brief History of Time and have to admit I didn't make it past the first few chapters. Fast forward and I grabbed this one. It is a lot easier to understand, although there are still parts that make me say 'Huh?' I also caught myself grinning every time I heard the Big Bang Theory as I immediately thought of Sheldon Cooper. Also, I actually learned a few things about string theory and a couple of other terms the guys throw around on the show. Overall, this one is no super overwhelming as I did make it through the entire thing.

If this is a book for the masses. Then I still feel dumb. Hold on tight until the end and all the concepts are put to work to describe what humans are likely experiencing.Favorite concept in the book is that 'intelligence is not really a great survival trait, bacteria will continue to thrive with no intelligence'.Certainly can't fault a person for trying to build their mental model understanding of the universe. I've decided that my passion for "Space" now includes pretty pictures, big rockets and the excitement of exploration. To go boldly where no-one has gone before...

It's an amazing but highly scientific speculative book (At the end) about the modern physics theories that could lead to a theory of everything, a search pursued by physicists since the great unification work of Isaac Newton. The reader will find a nice way to understand the main concepts of physics but some chapters are very hard to understand because the Intuition become insufficient to get the whole idea. Sure you will enjoy the journey that starts when you take the book and swamp into the pictures of an nutshell-like universe

Not as bright as A Brief History Of Time since this book here is supposed to be a sequel.Not to mention of course the repetitive manner of many major headlines that I already read in the Brief History book.But I must say, it's still insightful, especially when it comes to the last part of the book where biology and human fate were discussed.Prof. Hawking added some new thoughts and concepts into this volume that were not mentioned in his earlier editions.3 shiny stars for the last part of the book. the remaining 2 stars were already been given to the Brief History.

Though definitely interesting and important, this book doesn't live up to the legacy of A Brief History of Time. It is quite a bit more complex and, for someone of my level of physics knowledge, quite difficult to understand at certain points. In ABHoT, I never felt this was the case, as even the most unintuitive concepts were explained clearly and made comprehensible. Additionally, the "narrative" of The Universe in a Nutshell is jumpy and non-linear, and I found myself feeling whiplashed between various crazy cosmological theories.

A sequel of A Brief History of Time, with more recent researches and discoveries in theoretical physics field.He discussed the development of unified theory of all fundamental forces of the nature, as well as go deep into explaining some specific topics, such as string theory, M-theory, P-branes,..Just like reading his previous million-copy bestseller, be ready to travel in the surreal journey through eleven dimension world, with amazingly clear language, comprehensible analogies and occasional humor of one of the greatest minds in this century.

I could only read up until chapter 4. Each chapter had become too technical as I progressed. However, these are fell new things that intrigued me:The light emitted by star should have escape velocity more than its gravity otherwise, it becomes a dark star, and probably a black hole! (The first explanation for a blackhole).Light will change its direction by a small angle when it passes near a star because of the curvature of space-time produced by the mass of the starQuasars!

I guess that reading every book that was written by Stephen Hawking can't be a waste of time (especially as he himself works on defining better the definition of time).The book is very short and covers only few topics, relatively fast, but I guess it could be written a bit simpler. Even readers that have some understanding in physics will find themselves lost few times. The famous humor of Hawking dependently makes this book more fun to read.

"One, remember to look up at the stars and not down at your feet. Two, never give up work. Work gives you meaning and purpose and life is empty without it. Three, if you are lucky enough to find love, remember it is there and don’t throw it away."Beautiful images paired with amazing facts and information about our universe. A little harder to understand that Michio Kaku's works, but not quite Master's Degree level writing.

Maybe I'm too dumb or the audiobook wasn't the best way to consume it but this was really hard to follow. I guess I was expecting something more approachable to the every-man. There were a few things that I could follow and it was cool to see just over the horizon of my understanding for a few minutes, but at the end of the day I'm just glad that this book was mercifully short so that I didn't have to abandon reading it. I don't think I'll read any more of his books though.

This is the 5th book on astrophysics that I have read this year and I may be more confused about time, space, m theory, and the origins of the universe than when I started. Still this was delightful little book. It is more technical than an of the previous books that I have read and Hawking does attempt to simplify some of the ideas but they are still difficult to comprehend. The line 'intelligence may not be nesaccarv for survival, in fact it may get in the way' came from this book.

If you're into cosmology and theoretical physics then this book is for you. After I finished "Brief Answers to the Big Questions", I was so impressed and wowed by Stephen Hawking's thinking comprehension and vision so I started this book. In my opinion, "Brief Answers to the Big Questions" has everything this book can offer and even in a more simplified delivery for someone with very basic understanding of cosmology and theoretical physics but still curious about the universe.

Like others, I opted for the popular audiobook. It's a predictably heavy topic and i'm sure more went over my head than went in but the parts I could grasp I found incredibly fascinating; particularly wormholes and time travel in chapter five, and genetic modification in chapter six. What is also a pleasant surprise is how funny Hawkins can be and how he sprinkles popular cultural references throughout to help the reader relate to his theories.

Mr. Hawking has a great sense of humor that comes through in his writings. Much of this book was more than my P-brain could comprehend, but I appreciate his trying to simplify it for non-scientific readers. He and Carl Sagan were amazing in how they stimulate interest in science among young people. I particularly enjoyed his discussion of what the future of human DNA and AI may be as we incorporate computers within our bodies.

I wasn't quite as mind-blown by this one as by A Brief History of Time. I found many of the graphics distracting rather than clarifying. A lot of the same ground was covered in this as in the previous book, which many theories taken a little further, and a few extra ideas thrown in. Overall, I quite enjoyed it, just not quite as much as A Brief History of Time; definitely read that one first.

Not as easy to understand as his earlier works, but still, informative and insightful information from perhaps the sharpest mind on the planet. I would love to have an evolution discussion with Dr. Hawking, as a more biologically trained science teacher...his perspective from the physics side fascinates me!Thank you Dr. Hawking for all you do.

Cool concepts, but it glosses over a lot of details. I guess it's meant to convey big-picture information to Plebs like me without getting bogged down in proofs that I wouldn't understand anyway; I enjoyed it, so I guess it worked. This book is pretty old, though, so I can't help wondering if a lot of the science is more well understood and fleshed out today.

Considering how crazy high level these concepts are, I felt like I understood more than I expected to. I feel like I probably should have read this one in print because I would have comprehended more.....but I don't care enough to actually do so. Also, Stephen Hawking is kind of an ass, which sandwiched in science concepts and this very proper british voice is pretty funny.

I mean... I could follow some ideas?!? This isn't a reflection on Hawking however, I like his writing style but I chose to 'read' this book to challenge myself and read outside my comfort zone so mission accomplished? I dunno, maybe next time I want to revisit will buy a physical copy and have a bunch of index cards and highlighters at my disposal.

A very good concise read - hence "The Universe in a Nutshell". Truly, a good book to refresh my knowledge and understanding of relativity and the modern theories of physics. Did I mention it was full of wit and analogies that helped ease the understanding of these complex theorems? Highly recommended.

I agree with Marty’s comments. As much as I try, I still find many of the concepts difficult to grasp (and I have a background and affinity for science and engineering). But, I admire Hawking’s effort to show the wonders of the cosmos to the common man. I’m grateful the we had a brilliant mind like his and his tenacity in the face of his disabilities is inspirational.

I didn’t like this book. I was hoping for an explanation of things in the universe and how he knows those things to be true. Instead, he discusses imaginary histories and such with no convincing argument as to how anything is known. At best, he says, at least on some topics, we don’t know for sure, but part of this theory is backed up by part of another theory we believe to be true.

Read as an audiobook (in car).A bit heavy going at times and a bit old but well worth the effort (and repeat reads).A follow-up/update to his very popular "A brief history of time".The smatterings of humour her and there are entertaining.A brilliant mind - it is a real shame he is no longer with us.

This was ok, I found the first part of it a little repetative if you've read A Brief History of time. I preferred the later chapters that discussed DNA, intelligence, M-Theory, and life elsewhere in the universe. Still, Hawking does have a way of making very complex issues sound relatively simple. An interesting read for a few hours.

Read it twice separated by five years. Still a great read. Main meassage is that there is still alot to uncover at the very small and very large level of “existence” If you read closely you can see how mathematics has put a blinder over modern scientists. Come, seeling math,Scarf up the tender eye of pitiful mankind.

Ok, this is a 4.7 but I can't give it a 4.00 star. Hawking is a fabulous explanatory writer. If you are interested in physics, as the title states, this book is for you. Basically the physics of the Universe is simply summarized. I especially enjoyed the analogies of particle theory. Amazing science here.

I started reading the book, got bored in 30 pages, then took over this audiobook.I think audiobook is better if you are familiar with most of the astronomy, cosmological concepts or you have already read 'a beef history of time'.A always liked the way Hawking explains complicated things, here also he did it effortlessly.

Hawking blew my mind, but I don't know why! The concepts are explained as simply as possible, I suppose, but I still don't understand them. That's because they are incredibly difficult concepts that can only be appreciated by studying them thoroughly.Nevertheless, still a great and fun read, and a good way to show off.

I was excited to learn more about the universe around me in what was supposed to be book written for the common intelligence, but I found that Stephen Hawkins’ idea of common language is still too advanced for me to fully understand. I did learn from this book, but still felt that I was only able to comprehend about 30% of it.

Somehow a harder and more complex read than “A Brief History of Time.” The illustrations of all the concepts and theories was astonishing even for clumpy, early 21st century animation. Some very cool stuff but a lot more difficult to read than his other works for an novice interested in astrophysics.

A great book from a genius. Loved the way he walks the reader through the different concepts of our universe. Even-though it was an easy read for me as I am an Physics grad however I still enjoyed it.

What makes Hawking a nerd saint to me is the way he gives you five pages of theoretical physics on the possible properties of singularity as a sort of set up to a one sentence sex joke. Expand your imagination and have a chuckle.

This book is so delightful. Covers various aspects of our Universe indeed in a nutshell. The comedic timing of Stephen Hawking which is his signature writing style kept the pace going nicely. All the way from Einstein's ground breaking relativity papers to 11 dimensional worlds. I enjoyed it.

I tried to read it, thinking I would understand more about the universe, but I had to abandon it after several attempts to get into it. Turns out that I just don't care that much about physics even if Hawking tried so hard to encapsulate it in a nutshell for me.

Was interesting but difficult to understand and follow. I need to read it again in physical copy to take time and reread and look up concepts. I was only able to grasp a couple general ideas from the audiobook

It was way beyond expectations and pretty complicated especially for those who are not familliar with physics.his previuos books are essential to understand this book.I dont recommend it for folks want to put their first step into midern physics.

These are comments regarding the audio CD - Learned a little regarding The Big Bang theory and Black Holes but most was way over my head. The hard cover book might have photos and illustrations to help with the visualization.

This book would bring me up to date “...on all the developments in cosmological theory....”. IF I understood more than about 20% of the material and could remember more than 20% of what I think I understood. Audiobook performed by Simon

A little bit outdated, but still very relevant to today's physics. It's certainly a good read for those interested in challenging themselves with a bit of a theoretical physics that's being read in simple words.

Exquisite and sprinkled with Hawking's humor.I must add that the subject of this book has nothing to do with the new New Age babbling and rhetoric, that is just pick choose and twist for the purpose of picking choosing and twisting minds to dumb to understand at least a fraction and too full of themselves to admit it.Many of the modern physics hypothesis are derived not necessarily in a classic measurable experimental way but by the prediction and fitness to a mathematical construction or model.

One of the greatest thinkers of the 21th century, Stephen Hawking briefly explores the event horizon and life cycles of black holes, worm holes that could carry one through time and space, and a multitude of other dimensions in this thought-provoking novel.

This is a fascinating book. It's too bad that I'm not smart enough to understand even the "Layman's" explanations. Still a very worthwhile read. It gives a peek at the vast wonder that is the universe.

Welcome to a 'brane' new worldIn this book Dr. Stephen Hawking introduces the concept of p-branes.And time travel as always!This brilliantly illustrated book is best recommended for anyone who had lost sleep owing to the nagging mystery about the universe.Liked it!

The first two chapters were easy for me to understand. Even after having read two of Hawkins other books, It was very difficult to wrap my head around the remaining 5 chapters. The glossary helped clarify some of the statements/ theories.

Prof Hawking is a brilliant scientist but “A brief history of time” is better. The chapters aren’t logically built upon each other and the theories aren’t well-explained from first principles and are instead stated as facts. What results is that the reader gets lost between statements and observations as there are missing links that are not explained.

Although I understood maybe half of it, mr. Hawking succeeded in explaining the theories in such a way that it was understandable and readable. I like his humour too. Really enjoyed & learned a lot! Would recommend

I am sure that Stephan Hawking thought that this was simplified for the public, but it is very difficult to get your head around. It did explain some things and the graphics were lovely. But a very tough read.

Once again a well written book, although a bit more complicated than A Brief History of Time, which, after all, wasn't exactly childrens litterature. But definitely a great read and a bit of a mind-blower.

I got lost in the second chapter and I’m not sure I understood the majority of what I read. Stephen Hawking had a great sense of humor and it shows through this book even if the topics fly over your head.

Amazing book. I consider myself an absolute zero when it comes to the subjects of quantum physics, string theory etc. But I was actually able to grasp some of the concepts explained in this book. Stephen Hawking is one of the greatest minds of this planet and having a book explaining some of the most complex mathematical challenges that he worked on is amazing. Specially when it is so easy to follow and being able to roughly understand a lot of the concepts explained here.Of course I will need to read the book a few more times to try to make sense of some areas that are a bit harder to understand, but overall I recommend this book to anyone that is curious about how the universe works, including quantum mechanics, M theory and even time tavel. Probably not great if you are already knowledgeable about these, but I would still give it a go.5 stars from me for sure.

This was a super interesting, quite quick listen. I think based on knowing there are pictures that I would have gotten more from the book from reading a physical copy. I was doing so well following the book until he started talking about cosmic strings and them being in conical shapes, that got me pretty lost. So time travel is a bit beyond my comprehension I guess. I was understanding relativity a bit better than high school. But yeah overall this was just an informative book. Made me think about how future generations are going to be screwed for real estate space if we don't get some type of space travel going. How fun.Overall would recommend as a once off read. Would recommend the actual book over the audio book. Also would recommend if you like hearing a physicist be sassy... I love that about Stephen Hawking. He was smart and sassy. Rating is 3.5/5 stars.

"Shine bright like a diamond! "- Rihanna said about love, and I want to use it to describe about this book. It is easy for people like me - who never pay too much attention about physics, chemistry,.. or any kind of science - to understand, every words seemed quite academic now just come right to my brain, every theorem used to be so strange to me, now I grasp it. Reading this book, I can feel Stephen Hawking's passion in each sentences. By some ways, he passes me his flame passion. Now I am more curious about the world we are living, how it work, anh what it used to be. I just want to send him my love and my respect, I will support you every seconds. And I hope all of you will have excellent experience like me. Thanks!

Having read A brief history of time in French when it came out all those years ago I thought I would treat myself to this more luxurious edition of its sequel.The effect of this book on my mind was not as strong as I had hoped. Perhaps this is because I have read many other popular science books since then and indeed also studied physics; I am now much more familiar with notions such as space-time, quantum physics. and glowing black holes.Stephen Hawking did a tremendous job with his original book, it truly revolutionised the popular science genre, but perhaps due to its over focus on black holes to the detriment of other topics, this particular title is not a book that would be recommended to first readers of the genre.Perhaps stick to the original.

Outstanding!Hawking has the gift of explaining things of extreme complexity in a very simple way. The book is a pleasant intelectual trip into the laws of universe. For me as humanist, the book was eye-opening and, sometimes, mind-blowing experience. I finally managed to get some understanding of black holes, theory of relativity, m-theory, string theory, and few other things about physics and the universe.Besides having fun I learned answers to few important questions:- is it possible to time travel?- how long does it take until the universe will collapse?- how long time do human beings have until the Earth is not enough?PS Everything is random.Highly recommended.

Listened to the audiobook. The subject is very interesting and there is a gentle sense of humor. Still, some parts were hard to follow (even though I did two years toward a physics degree), maybe due to missing the illustrations or maybe just the depth/unfamiliarity of the subject matter. I think sometimes a handwaving explanation is more confusing than a detailed one, so even though I understand why the author wouldn't assume the reader understands calculus, etc., I don't know if glossing over such difficult/outlandish material really makes it any easier to grasp. I'll probably listen to this again sometime, or better yet, read the book.

Probably 3.5. Was really interesting stuff but I feel as though audiobook is not the best way to absorb the content if you don't already have extensive knowledge of physics. It's a lot to wrap your head around and fully take in, something I feel I would've been able to do much better it I'd read it at my own pace, and looked things up as I was reading, rather than the narrator's pace. There was also a lot of repetition, which I didn't mind too much, but I imagine that if I were a physicist I'd be a bit annoyed. So I feel it would've been better if it was either written for experts or dumbed down a lot more for novices, rather than trying to please both.

It's very possible that some of this went over my head. It's also very possible that this book is not well suited to audio format. Regardless, I found this a little disappointing.
